author: By James Krellenstein, Joseph Osmundson and Keletso Makofane
title: To Fight Monkeypox, Remember the Lessons of Covid and H.I.V.
description: How to keep another epidemic at bay this summer.
content: When Covid-19 cases were exploding across the United States in early 2020, public health officials remained in the dark, in large part because of major errors in developing a test for the illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Piccoli and Amy Julia Harris
title: Rockaway Beach Is Partially Closed. That’s Not Stopping These Beachgoers
description: Access is restricted along a popular stretch of the beach until at least mid-July because of work to protect the shoreline from coastal flooding.
content: When Barbara Lyn and a friend arrived at Rockaway Beach on Sunday morning, they found the perfect spot on the sand, near Beach 96th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: On the Coast of Alabama
description: Alexander Liebeskind tries to make a fresh start.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It’s commencement season, and students graduating from college typically find myriad ways to celebrate. Some find new and unusual ways to party. Others make crossword puzzles that get published in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Pelosi’s Husband Faces Drunken Driving Charge in California
description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was not with her husband, Paul, when he was arrested in Napa County on Saturday, a spokesman said.
content: Paul Pelosi, the husband of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol in Napa County, Calif., on Saturday night, according to the county’s website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Sokol
title: F.B.I. Investigates Basquiat Paintings Shown at Orlando Museum of Art
description: A subpoena raises questions about an exhibition of works “purported to be by artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.”
content: The ongoing cultural fascination with the life and work of Jean-Michel Basquiat shows little signs of dimming, whether it’s in the form of brisk sales for $29.99 Basquiat-themed T-shirts at The Gap, large crowds for Basquiat’s latest art exhibitions, or an actual canvas by the painter auctioned last week for $85 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Applebome
title: Ronnie Hawkins, Rockabilly Road Warrior, Is Dead at 87
description: Besides performing, he mentored stars like Robbie Robertson, Levon Helm and Rick Danko, who went on to form one of the most influential groups of the rock era, the Band.
content: Ronnie Hawkins, who combined the gregarious stage presence of a natural showman and a commitment to turbocharged rockabilly music in a rowdy career that spanned more than a half-century, died on Sunday. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Shattered Town
description: Families and loved ones are leaning on each other to cope with the Texas school shooting.
content: My colleague Jack Healy is in Uvalde, Texas, reporting on the school shooting that killed 19 children and two adults. He has talked to victims’ families about their grief and anger over police handling of the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What America Needs Is a Liberalism That Builds
description: You can’t transform the economy without first transforming the government.
content: Early in Joe Biden’s presidency, Felicia Wong, the president of the liberal Roosevelt Institute, told me that Biden was badly misunderstood. He’s been in national politics for decades, and so people look at him and “default to a kind of old understanding of what Democrats stand for, this idea that Democrats are tax-and-spend liberals.” Wong thought he wanted more: “What Biden is trying to push is much more about actually remaking our economy, so that it does different things, and it actually regularly produces different outcomes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Hard Truth: Gun Safety Must Be Everything That Republicans Fear
description: Republicans worry that gun safety laws could lead to national gun registries, insurance requirements and bans. I hope they do.
content: I find that the gun safety debate lacks candor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: A Balm for Psyches Scarred by War
description: MDMA-assisted treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder “represents real hope for long-term healing,” health experts say.
content: Nigel McCourry removed his shoes and settled back on the daybed in the office of Dr. Michael Mithoefer, a psychiatrist in Charleston, S.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: As Boris Johnson Stumbles, Labour Struggles to Offer a Clear Message
description: Out of power for 12 years, Britain’s Labour Party has made some gains, but its message hasn’t won back the rust belt regions that abandoned it in the last election.
content: LONDON — When Boris Johnson hit energy companies with a windfall tax last week as a way of providing more aid for struggling consumers, it was a bittersweet moment for the opposition Labour Party, which had been promoting just such a plan for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: ¿Quién es Federico Gutiérrez, candidato de la derecha a la presidencia de Colombia?
description: En la carrera hacia las elecciones presidenciales de Colombia, Federico Gutiérrez, un candidato de la derecha, es apoyado por una alianza conservadora similar a la que ayudó a impulsar al cargo al actual presidente.
content: En la carrera hacia las elecciones presidenciales de Colombia, Federico Gutiérrez, un candidato de la derecha, es apoyado por una alianza conservadora similar a la que ayudó a impulsar al cargo al actual presidente.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 29, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 29, 2022.
content: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about Baz Luhrmann and his new Elvis Presley film misidentified a subject. The person on the left is Schuyler Weiss, Mr. Luhrmann’s producing partner, not an assistant. Another caption misidentified a poster shown. It was for John Huston’s film “Moulin Rouge” from 1952, not the film “Moulin Rouge” from 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
title: No Grandchild? Six Years After Son’s Wedding, These Parents Are Suing
description: A couple in India are demanding that their son and daughter-in-law have a child or pay them $650,000 in damages. “This is an Indian parent thing,” their lawyer said.
content: NEW DELHI — After spending their savings to have their son trained as a pilot in the United States, Sanjeev Ranjan Prasad and Sadhana Prasad financed his lavish wedding back in India, along with a luxury car and an overseas honeymoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Jason Horowitz
title: Ukraine Battle Expands as Kyiv Launches Counteroffensive
description: “Hold on, Kherson, we’re coming!” the Ukrainian military declared as it pushed to retake territory in a key southern city.
content: KRAMATORSK, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers, seeking to spread Russian forces thin, launched a counteroffensive on Sunday in Kherson, the key southern city that Moscow considered so securely under its thumb that it had introduced the ruble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Why Gun Reform Is at a Stalemate
description: What happens when policy proposals feel like a personal attack.
content: It’s a nauseating, familiar cycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Julie Turkewitz and Flávia Milhorance
title: Los líderes de izquierda ascienden en Latinoamérica en medio de las dificultades económicas generalizadas
description: En las últimas semanas de 2021, Chile y Honduras votaron con determinación por presidentes de izquierda para reemplazar a líderes de derecha, con lo que se extendió un cambio significativo que lleva varios años ocurriendo en toda América Latina.
content: En las últimas semanas de 2021, Chile y Honduras votaron con determinación por presidentes de izquierda para reemplazar a líderes de derecha, con lo que se extendió un cambio significativo que lleva varios años ocurriendo en toda América Latina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: For Russian-Speaking Ukrainians, Language Clubs Offer Way to Defy Invaders
description: Many Ukraine citizens speak Russian as their first language. Volunteer organizations are helping them improve their Ukrainian and abandon “the occupiers’ language.”
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The teacher sounded her words slowly, careful to show which syllable to stress: Eyebrow. Cheekbones. Hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Lands Triumphantly on Opening Weekend
description: The film industry takes the estimated $151 million in North American ticket sales as a breakthrough after a long pandemic slump.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Top Gun: Maverick” finds Tom Cruise called back into service by a rattled Navy. A new threat has emerged, one that a younger generation of pilots can’t crack on its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: It’s Djokovic vs. Nadal, the French Open Rematch We’ve Been Waiting For
description: Djokovic, the world No. 1, and Nadal, the 13-time French Open champion, will continue their epic rivalry on Tuesday in the quarterfinal at Roland Garros.
content: PARIS — As the kids like to say these days, it’s on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan DiTrolio
title: Real Estate’s Next Move
description: Nikita Stewart, who became the editor of the Real Estate desk in  January, shares how she is steering the section into the future.
content: For Sunday readers of The New York Times, the Real Estate section is a sweet slice of escape, a treat to be enjoyed leisurely over a cup of coffee. Often readers find sanctuary in its pages, perusing photos of tree-lined Brooklyn blocks, brick townhouses and sprawling (envy-inducing) grassy lawns attached to even more sprawling (and even more envy-inducing) Hamptons homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Alexandra Berzon
title: A Big Lie in a New Package
description: A new documentary from Trump allies makes the latest case the election was stolen, but the group behind the claim has been assailed even by some on the hard right.
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Votes switched by Venezuelan software. Voting machines hacked by the Chinese. Checking for telltale bamboo fibers that might prove ballots had been flown in from Asia. After the 2020 election, Donald J. Trump and his allies cycled through a raft of explanations for what they claimed was the fraud that stole his rightful re-election as president, all of them debunked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Plane Crashes in Nepal With 22 Aboard, Government Says
description: The search for the plane and its passengers and crew was being hampered by bad weather.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — A search was underway in Nepal on Sunday for a small plane with 22 people aboard that the government says crashed during a flight to a Himalayan tourist destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Rangers Aim to Give the Hurricanes an Unhappy Homecoming
description: The home team has won each game in a second-round series that returns to Raleigh, N.C., on Monday with a berth in the Eastern Conference finals against the Lightning up for grabs.
content: In one of the last regular-season games of the year, the Carolina Hurricanes traveled to Madison Square Garden and beat the Rangers, securing the Metropolitan Division crown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Heddy Honigmann, Whose Films Told of Loss and Love, Dies at 70
description: A documentarian, she liked to engage her subjects — Parisian subway buskers, Peruvian taxi drivers, survivors of genocide — in conversations.
content: Heddy Honigmann, the Peruvian-born Dutch filmmaker whose humane and gently paced documentaries of Parisian subway buskers, Peruvian taxi drivers, disabled people and their service dogs, Dutch peacekeepers and the widows of men who had been murdered in a tiny village near Sarajevo, were stories of loss, trauma and exile — and the sustaining forces of art and love — died on May 21 at her home in Amsterdam. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The U.S. Justice Department will review the law enforcement response to Uvalde shooting.
description: The review, which came at the request of Uvalde’s mayor, comes amid criticism from parents and community leaders over how long it took police to intervene and stop the gunman.
content: The U.S. Justice Department said on Sunday that it will review the law enforcement response to the mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas, at the request of its mayor, Don McLaughlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: Escalating U.S. Sanctions on Russia
description: The chip maker Broadcom continued its acquisitive streak, buying VMware. Gas prices head higher. And a report will show if job growth continues to be strong.
content: On Wednesday at midnight, the Biden administration let lapse an exemption in the sweeping sanctions against Russia that had allowed the country to continue making payments on its foreign debts during its war on Ukraine. The Treasury Department issued the announcement just hours before the deadline. Russia is now hurtling toward a benchmark it has been intent on avoiding: a default on its foreign debt for the first time in more than a century. Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said Tuesday that the exemption was always intended to be temporary. Still, the decision represents an escalation in U.S. sanctions on Russia as Western countries try to increase pressure on its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Denton, David Zucchino and Yaqoob Akbary
title: Green Energy Complicates the Taliban’s New Battle Against Opium
description: The multibillion-dollar trade has survived previous bans. Now, the Taliban are going after solar-powered water pumps to try to dry up poppy crops in the middle of a national economic crisis.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — For years, opium has been the monster too big to slay. One Afghan government after another has pledged to stamp out opium production and trafficking, only to prove unable to resist billions of dollars in illicit profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Speedy and Upbeat, Leylah Fernandez Is Going Deep at the French Open
description: She outlasted Amanda Anisimova, a hard-hitting American, showing the kind of big-stage composure that got her to the final of last year’s U.S. Open.
content: PARIS — It is a new season and a different surface, but Leylah Fernandez, still tenacious and still a teenager, is back in the deep end of another Grand Slam tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: Ukraine, newly armed with Western weapons, is making a desperate attempt to hold its ground as Russian forces are close to capturing Sievierodonetsk, the last Ukrainian-controlled city in the Luhansk region, a province now at the heart of the conflict.
content: Ukraine, newly armed with Western weapons, is making a desperate attempt to hold its ground as Russian forces are close to capturing Sievierodonetsk, the last Ukrainian-controlled city in the Luhansk region, a province now at the heart of the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Janetsky
title: Who is Federico Gutiérrez, a right-wing candidate for the president of Colombia?
description: In the run up to Colombia’s presidential election, Federico Gutiérrez, a right-wing candidate, is supported by a conservative alliance similar to the one that helped propel the current president to office.
content: In the run up to Colombia’s presidential election, Federico Gutiérrez, a right-wing candidate, is supported by a conservative alliance similar to the one that helped propel the current president to office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Can Paramount Go It Alone?
description: The dominance of Netflix and Disney in streaming has forced many companies to join forces. So far, Paramount has gone its own way.
content: In January, the board of Paramount, including Shari Redstone, the company’s chair, met with a group of bankers to get an update on the media industry and to hear about potential deals that might help the company better compete with streaming giants like Netflix and Disney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Julie Turkewitz and Flávia Milhorance
title: In Latin America, leftist leaders are on the rise amid widespread economic suffering.
description: In the final weeks of 2021, Chile and Honduras voted decisively for leftist presidents to replace leaders on the right, extending a significant, multiyear shift across Latin America.
content: In the final weeks of 2021, Chile and Honduras voted decisively for leftist presidents to replace leaders on the right, extending a significant, multiyear shift across Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Leporati
title: After a Late Red Flag, a Thrilling Sprint to the Indy 500 Finish
description: With a few laps to go, Marcus Ericsson seemed to have the race well in hand. But a crash and a restart made him work a little harder for the victory.
content: What seemed like an easy, sure victory turned into one of the most dramatic finishes in recent memory, as Marcus Ericsson held on after a late restart to win the 106th running of the Indianapolis 500.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Tending Russia’s Dead as They Pile Up in Ukraine
description: Ukrainians hope that if they safeguard Russia’s war dead, they will be more likely to get back their own.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — They lie in white and black bags at 20 degrees below zero Celsius, but the stench is still overpowering. Filled with the bodies of 62 Russian soldiers, the bags are stacked in a refrigerated train car in a secret  location on the outskirts of Ukraine’s second-largest city. A spry, elderly train worker spun open the vault-like door to reveal the bloodied bags as the scent hung in the damp air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: A ‘Toothless’ Trip to Xinjiang
description: The U.N.’s top human rights official cozied up to Beijing on a trip to China.
content: The United Nations’ top human rights official spent six days in China, offering only limited criticism of China’s crackdown on predominantly Muslim minorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Stop Pretending All Books Are Written in English
description: Publishers routinely omit the names of translators.
content: About a decade ago, when I was an editor at The New York Times Book Review, we left the name of the reviewer off a cover review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris, Alisha Sawhney and Lisa Tarchak
title: America’s Teachers Offer Answers to the Education Crisis
description: “Our system had fault lines way before the pandemic.”
content: Teaching is a demanding job at the best of times, but these past two years educators faced countless roadblocks trying to do their jobs. Hopelessness, burnout and the call of other careers are just some of the issues teachers grappled with. “Most teachers know that our system had fault lines way before the pandemic,” said Kristin Fink, a middle school language arts teacher from St. Paul, Minn. “The last two years just emphasized how much our cultural fabric needs us but is unwilling to listen to us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: Fanciful Frocks From the Three P’s of Parties: Performa, Parsons and the Public Theater Galas
description: A week of alliteration.
content: Leave it to Performa, the performance art institute, to elevate a dress code into a full-on spectacle. On Wednesday, the arts group held a black-and-white gala honoring Adam Pendleton at 99 Scott Studio in Brooklyn. About 400 artists and benefactors attended the dinner and party with barely a stitch of color, including a magnificent pair of white Balenciaga pajamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Uvalde Needs Our Prayers
description: “In prayer, I find the answers I need or the strength I need.”
content: UVALDE, Texas — In some ways, it felt like a thousand pastors’ meetings I’d been to before. Seventeen ministers from around a dozen churches met in a church fellowship hall on a Wednesday morning around white plastic folding tables. Men and women shook hands, hugged and sat down together. We went around the tables introducing ourselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Announces 21 New Cardinals
description: The new “princes of the church” hail from places like India, Nigeria, Singapore and South Korea. They will be among those who help choose a new pope.
content: ROME — Pope Francis announced Sunday that he would create 21 new cardinals in August, selecting clerics from all corners of the world to reinforce the church’s global reach, as he has done with past choices to the rank of cardinal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: One Life Stolen, a Whole Family Shattered
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 29, 2022.
content: “You survive everything she did. And you couldn’t survive going to the grocery store.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: What Lia Thomas Could Mean for Women’s Elite Sports
description: Although the number of top transgender athletes is small, the disagreements are profound, cutting to the core of the debate around gender identity and biological sex.
content: ATLANTA — The women on the Princeton University swim team spoke of collective frustration edging into anger. They had watched Lia Thomas, a transgender woman who swam for the University of Pennsylvania, win meet after meet, beating Olympians and breaking records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $650,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: They Did Their Own ‘Research.’ Now What?
description: In spheres as disparate as medicine and cryptocurrencies, “do your own research,” or DYOR, can quickly shift from rallying cry to scold.
content: A couple of weeks ago, the crash of two linked cryptocurrencies caused tens of billions of dollars in value to evaporate from digital wallets around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: 5 Dead in Boat Collision in Georgia, Officials Say
description: Four other people were hospitalized. One of them was charged with driving a boat while under the influence, the authorities said.
content: Five people, including four from the same family, died in a boating collision on Saturday along a river popular with boaters outside Savannah, Ga., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: A Cafe Devoted to Remembering Duterte’s Drug War Victims
description: Served along with the lattes are personal stories from the staff, who are relatives of those who died in some of the thousands of extrajudicial killings in the Philippines.
content: QUEZON CITY, the Philippines — On the second floor of a nondescript coffee shop in a trendy neighborhood outside of Manila, patrons were welcomed by a marble gravestone with a tiny inscription written in gold: “Stop the Killings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Apple Store Showdown: Inside the Battle for Union Representation
description: Weary from the pandemic and pressured by inflation, retail employees of the tech giant are holding votes on whether to unionize.
content: ATLANTA — Sydney Rhodes’s frustration was rising. Seated at a hotel conference table across the street from the Apple store where she worked in Atlanta, she listened as her boss suggested to a dozen colleagues that they should be grateful to be paid more than other retail employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ¿Qué proponen los candidatos a la presidencia de Colombia?
description: Estas son las principales propuestas de campaña de los tres principales candidatos: Gustavo Petro, Federico Gutiérrez y Rodolfo Hernández.
content: Al acudir a las mesas de votación este domingo, los colombianos enfrentan una decisión que podría cambiar significativamente al país.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Can I Stop Isolating If I’m Still Testing Positive for the Virus?
description: Some people may test positive for the coronavirus for 10 days or longer, but interpreting those results remains difficult, experts said.
content: The Omicron variant of the coronavirus moves fast. Symptoms typically appear just a few days after infection, with viral levels peaking less than five days after the pathogen first becomes detectable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: States Rush Toward New Gun Restrictions as Congress Remains Gridlocked
description: Democratic state leaders from California to New Jersey are demanding immediate action after the Uvalde shooting.
content: SACRAMENTO — Congress failed to impose gun restrictions after the school massacres in Newtown, Conn., and Parkland, Fla., and there’s little confidence that 21 deaths at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, will change matters now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal, Skandha Gunasekara and Atul Loke
title: Lavish Projects and Meager Lives: The Two Faces of a Ruined Sri Lanka
description: A frenzy of building on borrowed money in the Rajapaksa family’s home district illustrates the hubris and mismanagement that led the country into economic collapse.
content: HAMBANTOTA, Sri Lanka — The international airport, built a decade ago in the name of Sri Lanka’s ruling Rajapaksa family, is devoid of passenger flights, its staff lingering idly in the cafe. The cricket stadium, also constructed on the family’s orders, has had only a few international matches and is so remote that arriving teams face the risk of wildlife attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Williams
title: To Change Baseball, an Ace Needs a New Title
description: Dave Stewart was a star player, an executive and an agent. He believes his sport’s path forward is Black ownership — and he is trying his best to make that happen in Nashville.
content: In the fall of 2016, when Dave Stewart was fired by the Arizona Diamondbacks after serving as the team’s general manager for two seasons, he was uncharacteristically short of words.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Leaving My Midtown Office After Work on a Monday Evening’
description: Left behind in a cab, a reflecting on the moments before dawn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: School Counselors on How to Help Students Recover From Pandemic Stress
description: Children are behind in social skills and struggling with emotional health, counselors say. They suggest eight ways to help.
content: American school counselors described a generation of students who missed crucial periods of social and emotional development during the pandemic, in an article we published Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: E. Robert Wallach, 88, Lawyer Linked to Reagan-Era Scandal, Dies
description: Convicted in a fraud case that took down an attorney general, he successfully appealed, and later defended himself in a retrial.
content: E. Robert Wallach, whose career as a heavyweight trial lawyer in California was overshadowed by his connection to one of the biggest corruption scandals to hit Washington during the Reagan administration, died on May 15 at his home in Alameda, Calif., near Berkeley. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris
title: Stampede Ensues After Loud Noise at Barclays Center Incites Fear of Gunman
description: Ten people were injured early Sunday morning when panicked throngs of people tried to escape what they thought was a gunman.
content: Ten people were injured at the Barclays Center early Sunday morning when a loud noise heard on the street outside incited panic, sending throngs of people running as they tried to escape what they thought was a gunman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Stirone
title: Manhattanhenge Is Back for Picture-Perfect Sunsets on New York’s Grid
description: Everything is coming into alignment for some of the city’s best sunsets of the year.
content: It’s time for New Yorkers to get very excited about the setting sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Keepnews
title: Alan White, Who Drummed With Yes and Ex-Beatles, Dies at 72
description: The invitation to perform with John Lennon, which he thought was a joke, led to almost 50 years with one of progressive rock’s foremost bands.
content: Alan White, a seasoned rock drummer who had worked with two former Beatles by the time he turned 21, but who was best known for his long tenure with the pioneering British progressive-rock band Yes, died on Thursday at his home in the Seattle area. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Mike Baker, Eileen Sullivan and Edgar Sandoval
title: As Shooting Continued, Officers Questioned Commander’s Decision to Wait
description: After several agencies responded to a school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, leadership fell to a small school district department created only four years ago.
content: UVALDE, Texas — From the first minutes after a gunman began shooting, officers descended on Robb Elementary School. Local police from the town of Uvalde. County sheriff’s deputies. Agents from the federal Border Patrol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: We Will All Mourn, and We Will All Be Mourned
description: A new classification in psychology has set off a debate over what should be done about “prolonged” grief.
content: After her 11-year-old son, Willie, died of typhoid, Mary Todd Lincoln’s “inconsolable” mourning brought on convulsions, her dressmaker and confidante, Elizabeth Keckly, wrote in an 1868 memoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘Zoey’s Perfect Wedding’ Review: The Bride’s Big Disaster
description: For affluent and educated 30-something New Yorkers, a favored set of the playwright Matthew López, a chain-hotel reception is as tacky as it gets.
content: There isn’t enough food, the D.J. is playing Styx instead of Beyoncé, and a line for the cash bar looks like a humanitarian crisis. The bride’s big day in “Zoey’s Perfect Wedding,” streaming via TheaterWorks Hartford, is predictably a total disaster. (Would we have been invited otherwise?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Collins, Albert Sun, Eleanor Lutz and Larry Buchanan
title: 78 Long Minutes
description: Families agonized outside Robb Elementary. And they waited.
content: Families agonized outside Robb Elementary. And they waited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Bianca Pallaro and Alice Fang
title: 362 School Counselors on the Pandemic’s Effect on Children: ‘Anxiety Is Filling Our Kids’
